questions.clue: This fire-breathing creature is often depicted with wings and scales in European folklore.
In Greek mythology, this one-eyed giant is best known for his encounter with Odysseus.
This Japanese water spirit, often depicted as a turtle-like creature, is known for its mischievous nature and affinity for cucumbers.
In Irish folklore, these small, bearded men are known for their shoemaking skills and hidden pots of gold.
This creature from Hindu mythology is a bird-like humanoid known for its strength and ability to traverse great distances.
For 200 points: This engine, improved by James Watt, was crucial in powering factories and transportation during the Industrial Revolution.
For 400 points: This invention by Eli Whitney in 1793 revolutionized the cotton industry by speeding up the process of separating seeds from cotton fiber.
For 600 points: This industrial process, developed by Henry Bessemer, significantly lowered the cost of steel production, leading to its widespread use.
For 800 points: This type of loom, invented by Joseph Marie Jacquard, used punch cards to control weaving patterns automatically.
For 1000 points: This British engineer is known for creating the first public railway line to use steam locomotives, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, in 1825.

categories.name: Poetry in Motion: Lines from Famous Poems

questions.clue: This poem begins with the line 'Two roads diverged in a yellow wood.'
In 'The Raven,' this line is repeated by the mysterious bird.
This poem by T.S. Eliot opens with 'April is the cruellest month.'
'Because I could not stop for Death' is the first line of a poem by this reclusive poet.
This poem by Dylan Thomas urges readers, 'Do not go gentle into that good night.'
questions.answer: Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night

categories.name: Architectural Wonders of the Modern World

questions.clue: This tower in Paris, completed in 1889, was the tallest man-made structure until the Chrysler Building in 1930.
Opened in 2004, this Taipei skyscraper held the title of the world's tallest building until the Burj Khalifa surpassed it in 2010.
Completed in 1973, this unique Sydney building is a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its sail-like design.
This modern engineering marvel in China, opened in 2018, is the world's longest sea-crossing bridge.
Designed by Santiago Calatrava, this complex in Spain is known for its futuristic architecture and includes a planetarium, an aquarium, and a science museum.

categories.name: The Great American Road Trip: U.S. Geography

questions.clue: For $200: This iconic highway, often called the 'Main Street of America', runs from Chicago to Santa Monica.
For $400: Known for its scenic beauty, this highway stretches along the Pacific coast from Dana Point, California to Olympia, Washington.
For $600: This national park in Wyoming is home to the famous geyser, Old Faithful.
For $800: This U.S. state's Highway 1 is known for its breathtaking views of the Atlantic Ocean and charming coastal towns.
For $1000: At approximately 3,365 miles, this U.S. highway is the longest continuous road from coast to coast.

final.clue: This city, home to a historic event in 1945 that helped shape the post-World War II order, is the capital of a country that borders eight others.
